{{About||the Vincentian sprinter|André François (athlete)|the French politician and diplomat|André François-Poncet<!--|the French race car driver|André François (race car driver)-->}} {{Infobox comics creator <!-- | name = André François --> | image = André François (1967).jpg | imagesize = | caption = André François (1967) | alt = | birth_name = André Farkas | birth_place = Temesvár, [[Austria-Hungary]] (now [[Timişoara]], [[Romania]]) | death_place = [[Grisy-les-Plâtres]], [[Val-d'Oise]] | nationality = French | area = | cartoonist = x | write = | art = | pencil = | ink = | edit = | publish = | letter = | color = | alias = | signature = <!-- optional --> | signature_alt = | notable works = | awards = | website = | subcat = French | birth_date={{Birth date|1915|11|09|df=y}} | death_date={{Death date and age|2005|04|11|1915|11|09|df=y}} }} '''André François''' (9 November 1915 – 11 April 2005), born '''André Farkas''', was a Hungarian-born French cartoonist.
==Life== He was born to an Hungarian family in Temesvár, [[Austria-Hungary]] (now [[Timişoara]], [[Romania]]), He studied at the [[Academy of Fine Arts]] in [[Budapest]] (1932–33). He moved to Paris in 1934 and entered to the atelier of the famous poster artist Adolphe [[Cassandre]] (1935–36). He became a French citizen in 1939.
He worked as a painter, sculptor and graphic designer, but is best remembered for his cartoons, whose subtle humor and wide influence bear comparison to those of [[Saul Steinberg]]. François initially worked for French [[Left-wing politics|leftist]] newspapers (''[[Le Nouvel Observateur]]'') and illustrated books by authors such as [[Jacques Prévert]], but gradually reached a larger audience, publishing in leading magazines of the United Kingdom (''[[Punch (magazine)|Punch]]'') and the United States (''[[The New Yorker]]''). He also did a masterpiece cover illustration of the 1965 UK Penguin paperback edition of [[Lord of the Flies]]. He became a close friend and collaborator of [[Ronald Searle]]. He was member of [[Alliance Graphique Internationale]].
He died in his home in [[Grisy-les-Plâtres]], in the [[Val-d'Oise]] département.
